summary: This is a cover letter from Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorneys to Judge Alison J. Nathan, submitting under seal a renewed motion for bail and requesting narrowly tailored redactions based on privacy concerns and the protection of confidential discovery materials.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The client of the law firm Cohen & Gresser LLP, who is the subject of the criminal case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell, and for whom a renewed motion for bail is being submitted.

persons.name: Mark S. Cohen
persons.context: An attorney at Cohen & Gresser LLP representing Ghislaine Maxwell, and a signatory on the submission letter to the court.

persons.name: Christian R. Everdell
persons.context: An attorney at Cohen & Gresser LLP representing Ghislaine Maxwell, and a signatory on the submission letter to the court.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the criminal case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell in the Southern District of New York, to whom the bail motion is being submitted.

connections.description: Mark S. Cohen is an attorney at the firm representing Ghislaine Maxwell in her criminal case, as indicated by the letter being submitted on her behalf.
Christian R. Everdell is an attorney at the firm representing Ghislaine Maxwell in her criminal case, as indicated by the letter being submitted on her behalf.
Both are attorneys at Cohen & Gresser LLP and are jointly submitting the court filing on behalf of their client.

events.title: Submission of Renewed Bail Motion
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorneys submit a renewed motion for bail to the court under seal, along with a request for public redactions.

locations: 40 Foley Square, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team is actively pursuing a renewed motion for bail as of December 2020.
The defense is requesting to file the bail motion under seal with proposed redactions for the public version, citing privacy concerns and the protection of confidential discovery materials.
The document references a Protective Order (Dkt. 36) governing the handling of confidential information, including financial documents, produced in discovery.
The case is United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell, 20 Cr. 330 (MN), being heard in the Southern District of New York before Judge Alison J. Nathan.
